data.text: Contents
Introduction

Overview - This document sets out the Trust's policy for the charging of Overseas Visitors, and in accordance with the Charging Regulations. Its aim is to provide a fair, consistent and equitable charging of qualifying Overseas Patients, whilst ensuring maximum income recovery for the Trust. This policy reflects the guidance set out in the  National Health Service (Charges to Overseas Visitors) Regulations 2015, which has been amended most recently by the National Health Service (Charges to Overseas Visitors) (Amendment) Regulations 2017 , and 2020 .These amendments have widened the scope of the Regulations, so it is imperative that the Trust implements these amendments to demonstrate their commitment to achieving compliance.

In any dealings with patients, including overseas visitors, administrative staff must comply with their legal duties in respect of avoiding discrimination. This includes compliance with the Human Rights Act 1998 and the Equality Act 2010. The Trust and staff working within the Trust must not discriminate against any person based on their having any of the protected characteristics (age, disability, gender reassignment, marriage or civil partnership, pregnancy and maternity, race, nationality, religion and belief, sex, sexual orientation) in comparison to a person without those characteristics. They must also have due regard to the need to:
eliminate unlawful discrimination, harassment and victimisation and other conduct prohibited by the Act;
advance equality of opportunity between people who share a protected characteristic and those who do not;
foster good relations between people who share a protected characteristic and those who do not.

The National Health Service (NHS) provides health care for the people who live in the United Kingdom (UK) and eligibility for relevant services without charge is based on the concept of “ordinary residence”. People who do not normally live in this country are not automatically entitled to use the NHS free of charge, regardless of their nationality or whether they hold a British passport or have lived and paid national insurance contributions and taxes in the past. An “overseas visitor” is any person who is not “ordinarily resident” in the UK. A person will be “ordinarily resident” in the UK when that residence is lawful, adopted voluntary, and for settled purposes. Nationals of countries outside the European Economic Area (EEA) must also have indefinite leave to remain in the UK in order to be “ordinarily resident”.

The charging regulations place a legal obligation on providers of relevant services in England to establish whether a person is an overseas visitor to whom charges apply, or whether they are exempt from charge. If they are not exempt then charges may be applicable for the relevant services provided.
Scope
Purpose - The Trust has a legal obligation to:
Ensure that patients who are not ordinarily resident in the United Kingdom are identified
Assess liability for charges in accordance with the charging regulations

Charge those liable to pay in accordance with the regulations - from  October 2017 the Trust is required to recover these charges in full in advance of providing them, unless doing so would prevent or delay the provision of immediately necessary or urgent services. Care which is clinically considered non-urgent and can wait until the overseas visitor's return to their home country, must be paid for in full before it is provided.
Recover the charges from those liable to pay.
Ensure that our process is open to scrutiny and is equitably and fairly applied.

This policy is relevant and should be used as a reference to guide practice for all staff employed within the Trust. If further information is required for clarity, the Overseas Visitors Team on your site or the Overseas Visitor Manager (OVM) are available to support and provide guidance.
The Overseas Visitors Team

The Department of Health and Social Care (DHSC) has recommended that an individual in every Trust should be made responsible for the management of patients not entitled to NHS care. The rules regarding free NHS treatment are complex and the regulations need to be embedded within the organisation through the specialist support and advice of a team who are competent and confident in operationalising these Regulations. The Overseas Visitors Team (OVT), led by the Overseas Visitor Manager (OVM), is responsible for this function at the Trust.

From an operational perspective, all staff, including clinicians and managers, have a responsibility to ensure that the charging rules work effectively. The success of implementing the charging rules also depends on the Trust's staff being aware and supportive of the role of the OVT.
Definitions

Refers to visitors who are nationals of or resident in the European Economic Area (EEA), which comprises the Member States of the European Union (EU) and Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein. For the purpose of the Charging Regulations, Switzerland is also included in this category. Following Brexit, EEA/Swiss nationals travelling to the UK will need to comply with relevant new immigration rules, as outlined on Chapter 10
The European Health Insurance Card (previously E111).
Primary medical, dental or ophthalmic services are outside the scope of the Charging Regulations, and therefore are free of charge for all
Treatment which a patient needs promptly: to save their life; or to prevent a condition from becoming immediately life-threatening; or to prevent permanent serious damage from occurring

Payment of the health surcharge is mandatory when making an immigration application. An individual who pays the health surcharge is only entitled to free treatment once their visa has been granted and not from the date the health surcharge was paid. Assisted conception services are excluded. From 01/01/2021, both NON EEA and EEA/Swiss nationals must pay the IHS if they are applying to come to or stay in the UK for longer than six months.
Nationals of countries outside the European Economic Area (EEA). These nationals must also have indefinite leave to remain in the UK in order to be ordinarily resident.

Routine elective treatment which could in fact wait until the patient returns home. For treatment clinically assessed as non–urgent, treatment must not be initiated until the estimated full cost of treatment has been obtained.

The NHS is a residency-based healthcare system and eligibility for relevant services without charge is based on the concept of ‘ordinary residence'. A person will be ordinarily resident in the UK when that residence is lawful, adopted voluntary, and for settled purposes. Nationality is no longer the qualifying standard.

An overseas visitor is any person who is not ‘ordinarily resident' in the UK. People who do not normally live in this country are not automatically entitled to use the NHS free of charge, regardless of their nationality or whether they hold a British passport or have lived and paid national insurance contributions and taxes in the past.
Provisional Replacement Certificate, issued to eligible EEA residents in cases where an EHIC cannot be produced

The UK has healthcare arrangements in place with a number of NON EEA countries, i.e. Australia, whereby nationals of either country would be able to access urgent healthcare free of charge. The agreement does not apply when the person has travelled to the UK with the purpose of obtaining healthcare.

The S1 (previously E121, E109, E106) form is a healthcare certificate that entitles UK and EU residents and their dependents to healthcare in another EU country on the same basis as a resident of that country. Only people who are in receipt of a UK exportable benefit (e.g. UK State Pension), or are posted overseas
but still pay NI contributions in the UK, can apply for a S1 certificate. Frontier workers are also eligible.
The S2 (previously E112) route entitles UK and EU residents to elective medical treatment around the EU region, funded by the patient's country of residence under certain conditions

Where the treatment is, in a clinical opinion, not immediately necessary, but cannot wait until the patient returns home. Clinicians will consider a range of factors to base their decision as to whether treatment can reasonably wait until the expected date by which the patient can leave the UK including: the pain or disability a particular condition is causing, the risk that a delay might mean a more involved or expensive medical intervention being required, or the likelihood of a substantial and potentially life-threatening deterioration occurring in the patient's condition if treatment is delayed until they leave the UK.

data.text: Roles and responsibilities within the Trust

The Overseas Visitors Team - The rules regarding free NHS treatment are complex and the regulations need to be embedded within the organisation through the specialist support and advice of a dedicated team. The Overseas Visitors Team, led by the Overseas Visitor Manager, are responsible for ensuring Trust policy is in line with statutory duties and national guidance provided by the Department of Health, NHS Improvement or NHS England. Individual responsibilities (i.e. Chief Executive). The Overseas Visitors Team will provides to the Finance Leadership Team (FLT) a bi-annual report seeks to assure the Finance & Performance Committee that the policy is being adhered to and where issues have been flagged, that they are being investigated.

Senior  Managers  (Managing  Directors,  Directors  of  Operations  and  Deputy Directors of Operations) within the Trust need to champion this agenda within the organisation and collaboratively facilitate the implementation of the charging rules. This is not only because the Trust has a legal obligation to make and recover charges from chargeable overseas visitors for the services they receive, but also to minimise additional financial burden on the NHS.

The recovery of charges from chargeable non-EEA overseas visitors also enables the collection of additional revenue that will support better health service delivery to all ordinarily resident patients.

Senior managers must ensure the Trust's compliance with its statutory duties and that legislation, guidance and advice provided by the Department of Health and Social Care, NHS Improvement or NHS England is followed. There also needs to be a strategic drive to translate legislative frameworks into operational policies

General Managers and Service Managers are responsible for ensuring this policy is  operationalised  within  their  departments  without  discrimination  and  that  all patients who  may be liable to charges are referred in a timely manner to the Overseas Visitors Team.
Managers will need to reinforce responsibilities during the local induction period and ensure all staff are aware of their responsibilities and that they receive training as and when necessary.
Clinicians - Clinical staff need to understand the principles of the policy and will inevitably become involved when a patient within their care is identified as an overseas visitor.
Clinicians are specifically responsible for;
Making the final decision as to whether treatment is immediately necessary, urgent or non-urgent.
Confirming if a patient is receiving services that are exempt from charging.

Confirming if a patient is a victim of specified types of violence (torture, female genital mutilation, sexual or domestic violence). It is not expected that the clinician will be able to provide confirmation in all cases, in particular in respect of victims of torture, domestic or sexual violence where the cause of physical injuries and symptoms may not be immediately apparent.
Confirming the patient is fit to travel to return home for further treatment.

The main role of Clinicians is to provide appropriate healthcare for all patients and to make decisions on their treatment based on their clinical needs. They will, at times, be required to make a decision on whether treatment is immediately necessary or urgent for those patients identified as not eligible for NHS-funded care. If it is the clinician who first becomes aware that a person may not be ordinarily resident in the UK, they should notify the Overseas Visitors Team and can, if appropriate, inform the patient that charges might apply.

While urgency of treatment is a matter of clinical judgement, this does not mean that treatment should be unlimited; there may be some room for discretion about the extent of treatment and the time at which it is given. In many cases, a patient undergoing immediately necessary treatment may be able to be stabilised, allowing them to be safely discharged and giving them time to return home for further treatment rather than incurring further avoidable NHS charges. This should be done wherever possible, unless ceasing or limiting treatment would precipitate deterioration in the patient's condition
The Overseas Visitors Team will work closely with clinical teams to ensure good communication and to prevent care being compromised wherever possible.

Clinicians are not expected to make judgements regarding the eligibility of patients to free NHS hospital treatment, and should not indicate to patients that treatment will be free unless and until this is established by the Overseas Visitors Team.

Frontline staff includes but is not limited to: admissions staff, clinic reception staff, central bookings staff, medical secretaries and ward clerks. Frontline staff are responsible for identifying overseas patients by asking relevant questions, copying EHIC cards and informing the Overseas Visitors Team in a timely manner. Although the majority of people will not be liable for charges, the same questions must be asked of every single patient, in every single department, whose chargeable status is not known. This is vitally important as this process should be equitable and transparent.
Overseas visitors team

The Overseas Visitors Manager (OVM) will provide advice and support as required to the Heads of Contracting and Senior Managers. In addition they are responsible for ensuring that the Trust policy is updated in accordance with national guidance set by the Department of Health and Social Care.

The Overseas Visitors Team (OVT) is responsible for providing additional training and support to the General Managers and Service Managers for their teams. They are also responsible for the general management of the overseas processes and training to support patient interactions.
EHIC and S2 income returns to the NHS Business Services Authority will be overseen and reconciled by wider OVT.

The OVT are responsible for identifying with support from their frontline colleagues potentially chargeable patients. The OVT will liaise with patients to establish eligibility for free care and invoice patients where appropriate. The team will work collaboratively with clinicians and will collate information for the clinician in order to help inform their judgement on clinical urgency e.g. anticipated return date.
The OVT will also provide expert advice and guidance to Trust staff as required.
The Accounts Recoverable Team will manage the debt collection process including taking payments over the phone, instructing debt collectors, arranging payment by instalments.

Heads of Contracting will provide support for complex finance issues including CCG liaison if required. They will also be responsible for coordinating an updated overseas visitors estimated price list on an annual basis. The Trust will use the NHS tariff for all final invoices following clinical coding unless a specific local tariff has been negotiated separately with the Commissioners.

The Deputy Chief Finance Officer will champion this agenda within the organisation and collaboratively facilitate the implementation of the charging rules. This is not only because the Trust has a legal obligation to make and recover charges from chargeable overseas visitors for the services they receive, but also to minimise additional financial burden on the NHS.
The Chief Finance Officer is responsible for implementing monitoring systems Trust-wide to ensure compliance with this policy and avoid breaches of the standards.
Exemptions to charging for treatment

This chapter sets out details of all services which are free at the point of use for all patients, and of groups of individuals who are entitled to receive healthcare on the same basis as an ordinarily resident person. Where a patient is claiming an exemption from charges, it is the patient's responsibility to prove that they fall under that category.
Exempt services

5.2.1 Accident and Emergency (A&E) services, including walk-in centres, minor injury units and urgent care centres. Service Managers are encouraged to engage with the Overseas Visitors Team on their site to obtain any necessary clarity on chargeable services to inform their staff.

5.2.2 Family planning services, excluding fertility treatment and termination of pregnancy. Diagnosis and treatment of specified infectious diseases, including routine screening and routine vaccinations, in order to protect the wider public health. The complete list can be found on Appendix 3.
5.2.3 Diagnosis and treatments, including routine screening and routine vaccinations, of sexually transmitted diseases.
5.2.4 Palliative care services provided by a registered palliative care charity or a community interest company.
5.2.5 Services provided as part of the NHS 111 telephone advice line
5.2.6 Treatment required for a condition, both physical or mental, caused by:
Torture
Female genital mutilation
Domestic violence or sexual violence (except where the visitor has travelled to the UK for the purpose of seeking that treatment
Exempt categories of person.

5.3.1 A child born in the UK is exempt from standard charges up to the age of three months, for standard care only and provided that they have not left the UK since birth. If any specialist care is required, i.e. cleft palate, their entitlement will mirror their mother's.

5.3.2 Refugees and asylum seekers, including failed asylum seekers supported by the Home Office under section 4 (2), of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 or those receiving support from a Local Authority under Part 1 of the Care Act 2014. Failed asylum seekers not supported by the Home Office/LA are chargeable from the date their appeal is rejected but courses of treatment under way will remain free.
5.3.3 Individuals receiving support under section 95 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (the 1999 Act) from the Home Office.
5.3.4 Children who are looked after by a local authority.
5.3.5 Prisoners and immigrations detainees;
5.3.6 Anyone receiving compulsory treatment under a court order.
5.3.7 NATO personnel and attached civilians plus their spouse/civil partner and any children under 18.
5.3.8 Members of UK armed forces plus their spouse/civil partner and any children under 18 years.
5.3.9 People who receive a UK war pension plus their spouse/civil partner and any children under 18.
5.3.10 UK Crown servants who are in the UK in the course of their employment, or who were ordinarily resident prior to being posted overseas, plus their spouse/civil partner and children under 18.
5.3.11 Any UK state pensioner resident in another EEA member state or Switzerland who has a S1 registered in that state. The person's spouse/civil partner and children under 18 are also exempt.
5.3.12 Those working or volunteering in employment overseas that is financed wholly or in part by the UK Government, plus their spouse/civil partner and children under 18.

5.3.13 Gypsies, Roma and Travellers - provided that they are properly settled here for the time being. All the circumstances of a person's case need to be taken into account when establishing entitlement.

5.3.14 Patients without a NHS number and/or a GP can still be entitled to NHS care as long as they can pass the “ordinarily residence” test, i.e. they can prove that they have been living in the UK continuously and lawfully. Although we would deliver emergency care to such patients, we would ask them to register with a GP before we can provide any non-urgent/routine care.
Vulnerable patients

Overview - When operating the charging rules, it is important to consider the position of vulnerable overseas visitors, including those who are living in the UK unlawfully. Although not all people who are in a vulnerable position are exempt from charges, priority must be given to their safety.

Destitute patients - Where it is advised that a patient is destitute or genuinely without access to any funds, circumstances will be reviewed on an individual basis, enquiries conducted and efforts made to support the patient. A debt may be written off in the accounts, however this does not mean that the debt is waived, nor extinguished - it remains in the Trust's records and can be recovered if the patient's ability to pay changes and will be reviewed as part of standard monitoring processes.

Victims and suspected victims, of modern slavery – human trafficking involves recruiting and moving a person, by force or by deception, for the purpose of exploitation. There is a National Referral Mechanism for identifying, processing and protecting victims of trafficking and modern slavery. Once a person has been referred, the competent authority will assess whether they are a victim of human trafficking or of modern slavery. If the conclusive grounds decision is positive, UKVI have the power to grant discretionary leave to remain for between  and 30 months. A patient will then be exempt from charge, and any treatment already under way remain free of charge until complete or until the person leaves the country.
The spouse/civil partner and dependent children of those exempt under this regulation are also exempt from charges in their own right, as long as they are here lawfully.
Maternity patients
Maternity services include all antenatal, intrapartum and postnatal services provided to a pregnant person, a person who has recently given birth or a baby.

All maternity services must be treated as being immediately necessary. No one must ever be denied, or have delayed, maternity services due to charging issues, and the patient should be encouraged to continue to access Maternity services regardless of their chargeable status. The safety of mother and child must be the Trust's primary consideration

As with all Overseas patients entitlement for free NHS care will be assessed and where this assessment identifies the patient as not eligible they will be advised of this, and the relevant charges will be applied.
Immediately necessary treatment
Immediately necessary treatment is that which a patient needs promptly:
to save their life;
to prevent a condition from becoming immediately life-threatening;
to prevent permanent serious damage from occurring.

The Trust must always deliver treatment which is classed as immediately necessary by the treating clinician, irrespective of whether or not the patient has been informed of, or agreed to pay, charges. It must be provided even when the patient has indicated they cannot afford to pay.

Although there is no specific provision for cancer patients in the Charging Regulations, it would still be a matter of clinical judgement whether treatment could be classed as immediately necessary. This does not mean that treatment should be unlimited - in many cases, a patient may be able to be stabilised, allowing them to be safely discharged and return home for further treatment, rather than incurring further avoidable NHS charges.
Urgent treatment
Urgent treatment is that which clinicians do not consider to be immediately necessary, but which nevertheless cannot wait until the patient can reasonably be expected to leave the UK

Where a clinician has confirmed that the need for treatment is urgent but they do not consider it to be immediately necessary, the Trust will make every effort, taking account of the individual's circumstances, to secure a payment equivalent to the estimated full cost of treatment in advance in the time before treatment is scheduled. However, if this proves unsuccessful the treatment should not be delayed or withheld for the purpose of securing payment.
Following the completion of care any additional costs incurred will be invoiced to the patient. Should the final costs be less that estimated a refund will be issued.
Non-urgent treatment

Non-urgent treatment is routine treatment that can wait until the date a patient can reasonably be expected to leave the UK. The Trust must not provide non-urgent treatment until the estimated full cost of treatment has been received.

Where a clinician has confirmed that the need for treatment is non-urgent this will be reassessed if the patient informs the Trust that their return date has been postponed for valid reasons. It will also be reassessed if the patient's medical condition unexpectedly changes and they inform the Trust.
EU Residents

Arrangements for European Union Overseas Visitors used to be governed by the European Union (EU) Social Security Regulations (Regulations (EC) 883/2004 and 987/2009 for EU member states, and Regulations (EEC) 1408/71 and 574/72 for Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland).
Now that the United Kingdom has officially left the EU, altogether different provisions apply as follows:

11.2.1 Nationals of any EU country, Norway, Iceland, Liechtenstein or Switzerland are now subject to immigration control, and as such, they must pay the immigration health surcharge when applying for a visa to enter and remain in the UK for more than 6 months.

11.2.2 Citizens of EU countries, Norway, Iceland, Liechtenstein or Switzerland who were lawfully resident in the UK on or before 31 December 2020 will continue to receive access to NHS-funded healthcare as long as they meet the ordinary residence test. They must apply to the EU Settlement Scheme before  June 2021.

11.2.3 Eligible family members may apply for a family visa or permit to come to the UK to join a citizen of a EU country, Norway, Iceland, Liechtenstein or Switzerland who was living in the UK on or before 31 December 2020. They should then apply to the EU Settlement Scheme in their own right.

11.2.4 Visitors from a EU country who fall ill or have a medical emergency during a temporary stay in the UK can use a valid European Health Insurance Card (EHIC) issued by their home country to access healthcare.
11.2.5 Planned treatment is not covered by a EHIC. Visitors from the EU will need to arrange a S2 form from the relevant health organization before travelling to the UK.
11.2.6 Visitors from the EU who are unable to present a EHIC, a PRC or a S2 may have to pay for treatment. Charges will be calculated at 150% of the national NHS rate.
11.2.7 Residents of Iceland, Liechtenstein and Switzerland will only be able to use a EHIC if their visit began before but ends after 31/12/2020. They may be chargeable otherwise.
11.2.8 Visitors to the UK from Norway will be able to access medically necessary care in the UK by presenting a valid Norwegian passport.

11.2.9 UK nationals living in the EU on or before  December 2020 can also apply for a UK-issued S1 upon reaching state pension age and drawing their state pension. They will then be entitled to free NHS hospital treatment, should they return
temporarily to the UK. Posted workers and frontier workers can also register a S1 with the NHS Business Services Authority.

11.2.10 UK nationals living and working in EU countries, Norway, Iceland, Liechtenstein or Switzerland on or before 31 December 2020 and their family members may be eligible to use NHS services without charge if they can produce an appropriate EHIC card or S1 certificate.

11.2.11 UK nationals who moved to the EU on or after  January 2021 should not expect to use NHS services for free when visiting the UK unless they have an EHIC, PRC or S2 to show that their healthcare costs are funded by the EU country where they reside, or another exemption applies.
11.2.12 In line with our longstanding commitments under the Common Travel Area, Irish citizens will not be subject to the immigration health surcharge.
Non-EU residents and the immigration health surcharge

People who live outside the EU, including former UK residents and UK nationals, are not entitled to free NHS care. They should make sure they are covered by personal health or travel insurance so that they can recover from their insurer any treatment costs that they are required to pay in advance. They will be charged at 150% of the NHS national tariff, unless an exemption applies to them or the service they are accessing, or they are covered by a reciprocal healthcare agreement between the UK and the other country.

The Immigration Health Surcharge came into effect on 6 April 2015, under powers in the Immigration Act 2014. The charge is paid as part of an immigration application depending on the type of visa or status. It is intended to ensure that migrants make a proper financial contribution to the cost of their NHS care.

As a general rule, NON-EEA nationals must pay the yearly surcharge in advance if they are applying to come to or stay in the UK for longer than six months. Once they have been granted a visa, and not before, they become entitled to free NHS treatment on the same basis as permanent residents, for the duration of their visa, with the only exception of Assisted Conception Services.
Once NON-EEA nationals are granted “settled status” or Indefinite Leave to Remain (ILR) they no longer need to pay the surcharge.

UK citizens who return to the UK on a settled basis will be classed as ordinarily resident so long as they can provide evidence of this (i.e. tenancy agreement, school admission letters, contract of employment). They will then be eligible for free NHS care immediately. This includes cancer care
Reciprocal agreements

Within the reciprocal agreements there are a number of variations in the level of free treatment afforded to visitors travelling to the UK. For all levels of coverage, it will be for a doctor or dentist employed by the relevant NHS body to provide clinical input into whether the required treatment meets a specific level of coverage.

It is important to note that the agreement is void when the person has travelled to the UK for the purpose of obtaining healthcare. Proof of nationality will need to be obtained before treatment can start. If the patient is unable to produce the required evidence, and their status is still unclear, the Overseas Team will be called in to assess the patient.
Patients covered by a Reciprocal Agreement are:

data.text: Assessment of eligibility and recovery of charges
A number of resources are available to the Overseas Visitors Office to identify overseas visitors:
Daily reports - patients without GP or NHS number seen or booked in, in the previous twenty-four hours or weekends.

Overseas Registration Forms - A&E staff will ask any patient without a NHS number or a GP to fill in an Overseas Registration Form on initial registration (Appendix  1).  These  forms  will  be  collected  by  an  Overseas  Visitors  Office representative every morning.

Ward referrals - if any ward staff believes that a patient may not be resident in the UK, they will ask the patient to complete an Overseas Registration Form and notify the Overseas Visitors Office in a timely manner.

Outpatient referrals - in cases where a GP/Dentist/Optometrist referral letter indicates that the patient has recently arrived in the UK or is a resident abroad then the booking team will contact the Overseas Visitors Office. If in the opinion of the medical staff the appointment is not classed as a two week rule or an urgent referral, treatment eligibility must be established before the appointment is made or any treatment is given.
External platforms such as the Message Exchange for Social Care and Health (MESH). This links to the ‘Spine' and is able to scan larger amounts of data and identify potentially chargeable patients.
The Overseas Office will then take the following steps:
14.2.1 Determine if the patient is ordinarily resident in the UK

The Overseas Visitors Office will conduct a patient interview and ask baseline questions to establish their potential overseas status. A flowchart of baseline/screening questions can be found on Appendix 2. All patients must be assessed against the test for ordinary residence in the UK.

All potentially chargeable patients who were seen after hours (i.e. evenings and weekends) or have already left the premises will be written to and asked to provide evidence of their ordinary residence in the UK. In accordance with the Department of Health's Regulations and Guidance, it is the patient's responsibility to prove their entitlement to access NHS care. Failure to do so will result in the overseas visitor being charged.
14.2.2 Determine if the patient has a EHIC/PRC/S2 or falls under a Reciprocal Agreement

The UK is currently able to recover the cost of treatment provided to any patient who is insured by a EU country via a EHIC/PRC/S2, including those patients who are ordinarily resident in the UK but are within scope of that arrangement. Patients whose nationality is covered by a reciprocal healthcare agreement are also exempt.
14.2.3 Determine if the patient is covered by an exemption in the Charging Regulations

Patients who are not ordinarily resident in the UK and are not insured by another EU country or covered by a Reciprocal agreement, need to be assessed against the exemptions in the Charging Regulations.
14.2.4 Make and recover charges from chargeable overseas visitors

Once  the  status  of  the  patient  has  been  established,  the  Overseas  Visitors Officer will get a signed Overseas Agreement to Pay Form from the patient and notify staff/update system as appropriate.

The estimated full cost of a course of treatment will be recovered in advance of providing it unless doing so would prevent or delay the provision of immediately necessary or urgent care. Patients with a valid Health or Travel insurance will have to pay the Trust for all treatments it provides and then subsequently seek reimbursement from their insurer.
14.2.5 Record the patient's chargeable status on their NHS Record
Records will be maintained by the Overseas Visitors Office, in accordance with DPA requirements, including the following information:
- Patient's name, address and telephone number
- Completed Patient Pre-Registration Form
- Copies of any Passports/Visas
- Completed Agreement to Pay Form
- Health Insurance details for insured patients
- Details of all treatment received, admission and discharge dates
- Home Office Evidence and Enquiry responses
- Correspondence sent to and received from patient
- Invoices raised
If a patient has indicated that they are a visitor to the UK, their overseas address must be entered in the system as the permanent address and the UK address as the temporary address.
Finance processes
Invoicing

15.1.1 A patient identified as not being eligible for free NHS care will be provided with an estimated invoice for all treatment and care provided unless an exemption applies. Should the final HRG differ from the projected one, adjustments will be made and this will either result in a refund or an additional invoice being raised.
15.1.2 The charges will be based on NHS tariff (national or local) plus the Trust's Market Force Factor (MFF) plus a 50% Department of Health overseas surcharge.

15.1.3 If an EU National can provide an EHIC/PRC (for unplanned immediately necessary or urgent treatment) or S2 form (for pre-planned treatment) the cost of treatment will be reported via the Overseas Visitors Treatment Portal (OVTP) by the Overseas Visitors Team. The Income Team will subsequently invoice the CCG for all Reciprocal/EEA patient activity.

15.1.4 Maternity patients will be sent an initial invoice for ante-natal care and a subsequent invoice covering intra-partum and postnatal care. Failure to pay will not result in the Trust withholding care, however, payment must be pursued in the usual manner and any debt older than three months reported to the authorities in line with current legislation.
Payments
15.2.1 The Overseas Visitors Team will be responsible for collecting payments in line with Trust guidelines. They will also liaise with Accounts Receivable regarding any outstanding accounts.

15.2.2 The Overseas Visitors Team will follow due process to report any debts by non-EEA nationals that are over £ 500.00 and have been outstanding for 3 months to the Department of Health and Social Care (DHSC). The DHSC will share this information with the Home Office who may use the data to deny any future application to enter or remain in the UK made by the overseas debtor.
Accounts receivable processes
15.3.1 The Accounts Receivable Team will be responsible for debt management and any queries relating to payment by instalment.

15.3.2 The Accounts Receivable Team will process credit notes which require a patient refund and will also make the refund to the patient. However the Overseas Visitor Team will have had to confirm the credit note was appropriate to raise, and it will have to be approved by an appropriate person as per the Trust's SFI's and Scheme of Delegation.

15.3.3 Established Accounts Receivable processes will be undertaken to manage the debt including direct patient liaison where possible, reminder letters and referral to debt collection agencies where appropriate.
Patient concerns, enquiries and complaints

A chargeable patient is liable to pay irrespective of whether they were told or agreed to pay charges. The Trust has no authority to waive, in whole or part, charges that are due. Communications with the patient both written and verbal clearly reference the The Department of Health and Social Care's ‘ Guidance on implementing the Overseas Visitors Hospital Charging Regulations' published December 2015, as amended in 2017 & 2020

If  a  patient  still  considers  that  they  have been  charged incorrectly  or  requires clarification to the content of their invoice, they should be referred to the Overseas Visitors Team. The Overseas Visitors Team will offer them the opportunity to meet and discuss their enquiry or concern.
Where a patient is unhappy with the healthcare that they have received, they or someone on their behalf and with their consent should use the NHS complaints procedure.
